awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Identifying how the ecological and evolutionary interactions between host and symbiont shape holobiont biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Although individual animals have long been considered a fundamental unit of evolution, we now know that each is really a co-dependent collection of host animal and microbes. This co-dependency reaches from ancient times through to the present day. Many animals depend on gut bacteria to process food and incorporate essential nutrients into the host's own tissues.  To untangle the importance of this partnership for hosts and symbiotic gut bacteria, this project will study a diverse and ecologically important social animal group, the turtle ants.  As social organisms, ants and humans share ways for acquiring helpful and harmful bacteria.  State-of-the-art molecular and genomic methods will be used to investigate ancient and modern influences on the symbiosis, the function of the bacteria for host health, and the means of passage and maintenance of the bacterial symbionts over millions of years.

Explaining global patterns of biodiversity and their drivers have long been central challenges in the fields of ecology and evolution.  Increasingly, it is becoming apparent that biodiversity is itself a function of interactions across different levels of biological organization.  Among the metazoans, symbioses with microbes are a defining feature, and individuals are integrated collections of host and symbiont cells, together defining the "holobiont".  By studying the diverse and tractable turtle ant system, this research will address the relationships between symbiosis and the dimensions of holobiont biodiversity with unprecedented clarity.  Specifically, this research will address: 1) the roles of time, biogeography, and habitat in host diversification (host taxonomic dimension); 2) variation in gut communities across host ant phylogeny, geography, habitat, and ecological niches (symbiont taxonomic dimension integrated with host taxonomic and functional dimensions); 3) the extent of codiversification for ~10 core, host-specific symbiont lineages, and the impacts of host phylogeny, geography, and ecology on symbiont transfer (symbiont taxonomic dimension integrated with host taxonomic and functional dimensions); 4) variation in genome evolution and innovation across symbionts with varying degrees of codiversification, and across genes with varying function (taxonomic, genetic, and functional integration of hosts and symbionts); and 5) symbiont function in light of symbiont genome evolution, host-symbiont codiversification, and host phylogeny, geography, and ecology (taxonomic, genetic, and functional integration of hosts and symbionts).

por.por_cntn:
Efforts to understand symbiosis, and symbiotic evolution, comprise major initiatives in the research of eukaryotic biology. As a defining feature of plants, animals, and fungi, symbioses with microorganisms have been argued to be ubiquitous in many organisms. But how do symbioses function and how do they impact host biology? At the same time, how and why do these interactions change over time, with the swapping of partners and the functions they bring with them? To address these questions we focused on ants, diverse ecosystem engineers whose symbioses with internally housed microorganisms have been disproportionately understudied. Beyond a comprehensive set of investigations on symbiotic bacteria in the turtle ant genus Cephalotes, we also studied the symbiotic bacteria across a range of herbivorous and predatory ants though a combination of barcoding and genomic methodologies.

In parallel to recently published studies for other insects, our work showed that many ants do not harbor large symbiotic communities within their digestive systems. And through collaborative efforts, we have helped to further show that such symbioses are concentrated in ants feeding at extreme ends of the food chain. In a barcode-based study across one such group, predatory army ants from the subfamily Ecitoninae, we used bacterial 16S rRNA gene sequences to show that some ant lineages have engaged in symbioses with the same specialized bacteria for tens of millions of years. But in a similar study on invasive Argentine ants, which have more recently come to consume a nitrogen-limited, herbivore-like diet, we found little evidence for high symbiotic biomass, for the presence of long-specialized gut bacteria, or for useful forms of symbiont-encoded nitrogen-metabolism.

In a more ancient herbivorous lineage, i.e. ants of the genus Dolichoderus, genomic and phylogenetic efforts from a collaborative study suggested very different symbiosis biology, with evidence for long-term symbiont specialization, symbiont-mediated nitrogen-recycling, and amino acid biosynthesis. We conclude that while ongoing shifts in ant diets may not incorporate or require the services of symbiont-mediated nitrogen-metabolism, more anciently evolved ant herbivores like Dolichoderus and distantly related carpenter ants, do engage with specialized, abundant, and highly integrated bacterial symbionts, with a potential to improve their nutrient economies.

Recognizing that genome content cannot perfectly indicate what symbionts do for their hosts, we performed manipulative experiments on herbivorous, turtle ants to understand if their gut bacteria might recycle nitrogen, and if such nitrogen might be acquired by ant hosts. Through use of antibiotic bacterial removal, stable nitrogen isotope labeling, and mass spectrometry, we showed that gut bacteria do indeed recycle at least one form of nitrogen waste, urea, and that adult worker ants acquire the recycled nitrogen in large quantities. A metagenomic analysis across 17 species of turtle ant illustrated that abilities to recycle various forms of nitrogen-waste, including urea and uric acid, are partitioned across distinct symbiotic lineages, which have retained these functions for tens of millions of years. In contrast, we found that nearly all bacteria encoded capacities to make amino acids, raising questions on the forces behind such redundancy and the identities of the nutritional mutualists.

Our results combine to suggest heightened influence for symbiosis in a subset of ant taxa, and to reinforce the idea that symbiosis is of special importance in animals with extreme, or imbalanced diets. Emerging from the extensive research of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs, these findings have helped to establish the turtle ant system as a model for symbiosis. And through future efforts toward a greater understanding on the evolution of such specialized turtle ant symbioses, we aim to further develop this system as an exemplar for research into how and why symbioses change over time.
